sourceDesc.p: Created from original research by members of CWRC/CSÉC unless otherwise noted.

div.head: NORMANDIE[N]omanide hath on the north ᶂyde thereof the narrow reas , that [ɼ]eperate England & france & [on all [ſ]ydes els is enuyrond with ɼeuerall countries & prounces fo Edance]. From wheue this Duchie taketh ɳame the name it [ſ]elf of Normandie doth declare to wiz North mandie, that is the dwelling or religion of the men of the North, for from No[ʋʋ]ay otherwife North ʋʋay came Role (afterward called Ŗobert) with this [Ɲ]orthmen , and of charles the limple King of france hee and people obtayned heere there habitation , about the yeare of ʋʋe Lord.912. This Pro[ʋ]ince of Normandie is a mo[ſ]te plealant & ferrilfolie [ſ]owel [ſ]urnifhed of all neceﬀaries as fildome anyplace better. hath great flore of ſleſb and ſilb. of corne , and ʋʋad much wyne it harth not there growing through Paris pa{ſſ}eth by roan the cheif citie of this prouince , All the corne feilds ad alfo the high wayes & paſſages , are fet & planted about with fiutrtyees efpitially aples & beares , which yeideth great aboundance of gider & perry , The riuer of Seine (as a [ſ]oreſaid) pa][ſi]ng by Roam falleth into the ſea at Haure de grace or [neʋʋbauen], where rhips arryuing do come vp the riuer to Ŗoan, which maketh the citie of great trade & trafique of marchandife.
